Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Real-Time Big Data Based Decision Support System for Water Use
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide accurate and timely precipitation forecasts for water resource management during rainfall and hydrological extremes including intense flooding and droughts events. This I-Corps team has developed a unique high resolution weather forecasting model using a high-performance computer framework that employed all available local weather observations and state-of-the-art local doppler radar data to improve local precipitation forecasts on a short-term basis. In conjunction with precipitation forecasts, our system will support water resources related decision-making. A web-based service to provide these pinpoint rainfall forecasts and other related hydrological data products will be available. Operations managers of businesses and government agencies (i.e., water districts, agricultural farms, insurance companies, energy companies) who rely on very accurate and precise rainfall forecasts to make economic-based decisions will be able to have quick access to customized rainfall forecasts and hydrological products at their user-defined locations. During short-term hydrological extremes, these pinpoint accurate rainfall forecasts and products will improve the efficiency and decision-making abilities within the companies and agencies themselves, and it will help them to better communicate their decisions to their end-users and the public.

This I-Corps project will employ a high-resolution weather forecasting model. It can have a horizontal resolution of 1 km or finer and uses specific 3D-Variational data assimilation methods which incorporate all available real-time weather observations from multiple sources. These input sources include satellite data (e.g., GOES-R), weather station and rain gauge data, quantitative precipitation estimates from local doppler radars, and other global and regional forecasting models (e.g., NOAA?s High Resolution Rapid Refresh and North American Model). The model can be executed separately for any specific region and location of interest to the end-user, can extract pinpoint rainfall forecasts, and can be updated every 3 or 6 hours depending on the circumstance. Other hydrological products available from the project that can also assist in decision support such as drought conditions (e.g., soil moisture and drought severity indices) and water levels of local reservoirs. It is anticipated that the products from this high-resolution modeling and big-data system will provide guidance to support water management and consumption decisions for government agencies and the private sectors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The NSF I-Corps team SJSU Hydro presents a tool to support real-time big data collection, monitoring and computation and prediction of water resources of California using hierarchical modeling based on regional computing and estimation. The state-of-the-art tool that incorporates analysis on satellite data, weather data, drought condition and water usage reports. Using high performance computing and big data applications, the team provides real time water analyses, forecast information (short- and mid-range quantitative precipitation, water consumption outlook), and guidance to support water management and consumption decisions for government agencies and private sectors (i.e., agriculture sectors).

Broader of Impacts:

Manipulation and delivery of the products in real time to end users, and so they can be better prepared. Currently, the team is providing a real time high resolution (1- km) precipitation forecasts, wildfire warnings, wind energy estimation in the San Francisco Bay Area. It can be considered successful completion of this project and broader of impacts.

Summarize the Outcomes:

The team SJSU Hydro conducted more than 100 interviews of different farmers and employees in the agriculture sector. The results show that the agriculture sector has a well-established ecosystem. Although short-term weather forecasts would be beneficial for agriculture related activities, it is not a critical component. Farmers or employees in the agriculture sector often find ways to mitigate their losses. The short term weather forecast products are "nice to have" rather than "must have".  

The team pivoted the research and development efforts toward a new potential market and customer segment: renewable energy. The goal was to determine whether or not our short-term weather model was suitable for being in the market within renewable energy forecasting, particularly wind energy and solar energy.

Wind energy companies and developers need to assess if winds blow over that area consistently enough to generate energy at about 40-50% of the turbines maximum potential over a year. Wind energy companies usually have multiple projects of future wind farms in a "pre-construction" phase. For land-based projects, they typically install meteorology observation towers, usually 60-100 meters high, for wind energy assessment purposes. However, for offshore wind projects, they will either use weather modeling or floating wind lidars to remotely gather wind data above. In general, the winds should be blowing at a steady rate for most of the time, but with winds that are not too fast to damage the wind turbines. Winds need to be blowing at least 3-4 m/s for blades to begin turning. Operators will shut down the wind turbine by rotating the blades so they will not move at around 25 m/s. 

Energy traders would be possible customers of these weather products. They need to know in advance the ranges and uncertainty of wind energy power production, particularly in the next 12-48 hours. Changes in wind speeds over the day cause wind power production to fluctuate in location and in time. This wind speed uncertainty needs to be understood by power system operators to make sure there is a balance between supply and demand. If enough energy cannot be produced then the utility company will need to get it from somewhere else, if there is demand.

Wind energy forecast errors could be as much as 10% of total generator energy income, stressing a critical need to manage the risks of unexpected levels of generation. According to our research, slight inaccuracies in wind energy supply, especially if the demand is high, could cost a large wind farm company as much as 30 to 50 thousand dollars per day at medium sized utility wind farm, if wind forecasts are off more than 3 m/s.

We learned that wind or solar energy companies are using output from many different forecasts from different time ranges with different methods. Machine learning techniques are for short-term forecasts (0-3 hour), numerical prediction models for 3-24 hour out and an ensemble prediction system for long-range forecasts 1-10 days out. Short-term forecast products are updated every 5-10 minutes while 1-day forecasts are updated as much as 12 times per day, and long-range forecasts 4 times per day. From ensemble output, many companies use statistical and probability methods like beta distribution to put a forecast together for a particular location with ranges of uncertainty values.

The main key outcome for our project after gathering information from interviewing in the field is that our short-term modeling framework, as it exists now, is not currently designed for wind and renewable energy using a big data approach. Our current design is only one piece of the puzzle.

We have come to the general conclusion that more research in the lab is needed on how to combine machine-learning algorithms for short term forecasting (0-3 hour), an ensemble suite of model runs for a more state-of-the-art, proven, and more accurate statistical methods to incorporate real-time data for forecast improvement.
